Name: Contract Information (ContractInformation2Orion **)

Documentation.Description:
Basic Concepts

ContractInformation2Orion is a REST based client that exposes a @POST method via which an external provider will be able to send the marketplace data on the cost of energy, the cost of energy produced by DERs and the cost of system transmission power plants.

Basic Design Principles

The following picture gives a snapshot of the java classes (and the interaction among these) that have been developed for ContractInformation2Orion:


Figure 1: Contractinformation2orion domain model

DSE Interwork

This DSE does not interact with any other WP4 DSE.

GE Dependancies

The implementation of this DSE is working with an instance of ORION v0.14.

Usage:
Installation guide

IMPORTANT: we kindly remind you that this software module is strictly tight to the use of ORION Context Broker GE thus meaning that you should have previously set up an ORION instance of yours. Please have a look at ORION GE documentation at the following link publishsubscribe-context-broker-orion-context-broker

Download the artefact (in the form a .war file) from the download section.
Open the .war file (you can use an appropriate software like “winRar”), open the “contractinformation2orion.properties” file located in the following directory: WEB-INF/classes/ and then amend the following configuration properties: 

contractinformation2orion.orionServerUrl = http://(your ORION instance URL):1026
contractinformation2orion.registerContexPath = NGSI10/updateContext

Save the changes to the .properties file and deploy the .war file on a Tomcat application server using the “Tomcat Web Application Manager” (see attached screenshot). We recommend you to use an updated version of Tomcat; we have used Apache Tomcat 7.xx.


Figure 1: "How to the deploy the contractinformation2orion .war file

To verify that the deploy of the contractinformation2orion application was done successfully and that it consequently runs, you have to type the following URL in a common browser like Google Chrome or Microsoft Internet Explorer: 

http://(your tomcat ip)/contractinformation2orion/rest/sendContractInformationData

and you should get a page like the following (see attached screenshot).


Figure 2: Test "sendContractInformationData" GET method in a browser

If the previous page appears, the contractinfromation2orion application is correctly deployed.

Usage guide

Now, in order to send a “Contract Information Event” to ORION, use a REST client such as DHC - REST/HTTP API Client chrome extension (see attached screenshot):


Figure 3: Send a "Contract Information Event" to ORION

Please fill in with the following parametres:
SERVICE (POST) 

http://(your tomcat ip)/contractinformation2orion/rest/sendContractInformationData

HEADERS 

Content-Type: application/xml

BODY 

<contractInformation 
contractInformationID=" _(a unique identifier of a set of cost information)_ " 
costOfEnergyProducedByDERS=" _(cost of energy produced by DERS)_ " 
costOfSystemTransmissionPowerPlants=" _(cost of system transmission power plants)_ " 
energyCost=" _(cost of energy)_ " 
validityStartDate=" _(date from when cost information are valid)_ " 
validityEndDate=" _(date till when cost information are valid)_ "/>

and finally click the SEND button.

If you get 200 OK in the HTTP Response, you should have submitted a “contract information event” to ORION.

To verify that a new “contract information event” has been saved into ORION, an entity of the following type should be created (or updated in case it already exists) in the NoSQL DB underlying ORION (i.e. MongoDB):

  },
  "attrs" : [{
      "name" : "currentTime",
      "type" : "long",

      "creDate" : _(date of attribute creation)_,

    }, {

      "type" : "currency",
      "value" : " _(cost of energy produced by DERS)_ ",
      "creDate" : _(date of attribute creation)_,
      "modDate" : _(date of attribute last update)_
    }, {

      "type" : "currency",
      "value" : " _(cost of energy produced by DERS)_ ",
      "creDate" : _(date of attribute creation)_,
      "modDate" : _(date of attribute last update)_
    }, {

Address/Protocol

The address of the REST call invoking the ContractInformation2Orion service depends on the IP address/port of the application server where the module is going to be deployed. 

EXAMPLE: http://(your tomcat ip)/contractinformation2orion/rest/sendContractInformationData

Protocol: HTTP

Commands

The following HTTP commands can be used to manipulate the data controlled by the DSE:
  • HTTP GET command used to test if the module has been properly installed; a simple XML, such the one shown below, is expected as output:

<contractInformation>
<contractInformationID>22222</contractInformationID>
<costOfEnergyProducedByDERS>12.3</costOfEnergyProducedByDERS>
<costOfSystemTransmissionPowerPlants>11.4</costOfSystemTransmissionPowerPlants>
<energyCost>2.4</energyCost>
<currentTime>1434964082</currentTime>
<validityStartDate>1434964082</validityStartDate>
<validityEndDate>1434965582</validityEndDate>
</contractInformation>

  • HTTP POST to send new information to the module.

Endpoints

The base URI to invoke the rest method exposed by ContractInformation2Orion is: 

http://(your tomcat ip)/contractinformation2orion/rest/sendContractInformationData

This is a POST method which needs the following parameters to be submitted: 

contractInformationID =  _(external provider’s contract ID)_
costOfEnergyProducedByDERS =  _(cost of energy produced by DERs)_
energyCost =  _(cost of energy)_
costOfSystemTransmissionPowerPlants =  _(cost of system transmission power plants)_
validityStartDate =  _(start date of contract validity)_
validityEndDate    =  _(end date of contract validity)_

Overview:
What you get

ContractInformation2Orion is a REST service (developed in Java) which allows clients (e.g. Retailers) to register data about cost of energy produced from the DERs, costs of transmission system and power plants, energy costs into an instance of ORION Context Broker GE.

This component can be eventually re-used and customized to fulfill the general need of having a REST service which is connected to the ORION GE.

Why to get it

A reference implementation of a REST service which is connected to the ORION GE.

Target Usage

  • Retailers (to upload information on cost of energy produced from the DERs, costs of transmission system and power plants, energy costs)
  • Third-party applications (such as those developed by SMEs involved in Phase3)
